items.title: Swift Logging
items.content_html:
As I previously mentioned, my new app TimeStack is nearing its release date. One of the final tasks on my to-do list is to include the ability to send logs as part of a support request. This requires a solution for persisting logs locally so that they can be attached to an email. In the past, I have used third-party frameworks like CocoaLumberjack to achieve this. However, I wanted to avoid adding another dependency and decided to test out Apple’s OSLog framework. It includes the OSLogStore feature, which retrieves an array of log entries. This seemed like an ideal solution for my needs, but as I discovered, it has some issues.

Peter Steinberger conducted an in-depth examination of OSLogStore in his article “Logging in Swift," and highlighted its strengths and challenges. Despite initial issues, it appears that OSLogStore is now a reliable and robust tool for logging.

Fetching entries is as simple as using OSLogStore getEntries function.

  let allEntries = try logStore.getEntries(
    with: .reverse,
    at: oneHourAgo,
    matching: NSPredicate(format: "subsystem = %@", subsystem))
}

After implementing OSLogStore, I encountered several issues that caused concern. Firstly, logs were not being saved between app launches, and secondly, retrieving logs took an excessive amount of time. In particular, on two devices (iPhone 13 and iPhone XR), fetching logs consistently took over 10 seconds.

Upon researching the issue, I found no similar complaints online. I reached out to Apple Technical Support for assistance, but the engineer could not provide a clear explanation. He did mention that the system log is optimized for writing, not reading and that the log size can vary significantly between devices, making it difficult to pinpoint the cause of the slow retrieval time.

The system log is optimized for writing, not reading.

Given the uncertainty surrounding the performance of OSLogStore, I decided to temporarily set it aside and re-evaluate it at the next WWDC conference.
items.content_text: As I previously mentioned, my new app [TimeStack](https://sullivans.ca/2023/01/05/ive-been-an.html) is nearing its release date. One of the final tasks on my to-do list is to include the ability to send logs as part of a support request. This requires a solution for persisting logs locally so that they can be attached to an email. In the past, I have used third-party frameworks like [CocoaLumberjack](https://github.com/CocoaLumberjack/CocoaLumberjack) to achieve this. However, I wanted to avoid adding another dependency and decided to test out Apple's OSLog framework. It includes the [OSLogStore](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/oslog/oslogstore) feature, which retrieves an array of log entries. This seemed like an ideal solution for my needs, but as I discovered, it has some issues. Peter Steinberger conducted an in-depth examination of OSLogStore in his article ["Logging in Swift,"](https://steipete.com/posts/logging-in-swift/) and highlighted its strengths and challenges. Despite initial issues, it appears that OSLogStore is now a reliable and robust tool for logging. Fetching entries is as simple as using OSLogStore `getEntries` function. ```swift let allEntries = try logStore.getEntries( with: .reverse, at: oneHourAgo, matching: NSPredicate(format: "subsystem = %@", subsystem)) } ``` After implementing OSLogStore, I encountered several issues that caused concern. Firstly, logs were not being saved between app launches, and secondly, retrieving logs took an excessive amount of time. In particular, on two devices (iPhone 13 and iPhone XR), fetching logs consistently took over 10 seconds. Upon researching the issue, I found no similar complaints online. I reached out to Apple Technical Support for assistance, but the engineer could not provide a clear explanation. He did mention that the system log is optimized for writing, not reading and that the log size can vary significantly between devices, making it difficult to pinpoint the cause of the slow retrieval time. > The system log is optimized for writing, not reading. Given the uncertainty surrounding the performance of OSLogStore, I decided to temporarily set it aside and re-evaluate it at the next WWDC conference.

Finished reading: [Fall of Giants (The Century Trilogy, Book 1)](https://micro.blog/books/9781101543559) by Ken Follett üìö
This book is very long, but I enjoyed it enough to start Book 2 in the series.

items.content_html: I’ve been an iOS developer for almost a decade now and have had the opportunity to work on some really cool apps that millions of people have used. But I’ve never released my own app until now. TimeStack is in the final stages of beta testing and I’m aiming to release it in the next few weeks. I’m so excited to finally be able to share this project with everyone!
items.content_text: I've been an iOS developer for almost a decade now and have had the opportunity to work on some really cool apps that millions of people have used. But I've never released my own app until now. [TimeStack](https://www.timestack.ca) is in the final stages of beta testing and I'm aiming to release it in the next few weeks. I'm so excited to finally be able to share this project with everyone!

items.title: Should the PGA Tour worry about LIV golf?
items.content_html:
I have been a golf fan for many years, and I have always enjoyed watching some of the greatest players in the game, like Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson, compete at the highest level. However, the recent emergence of the LIV golf tour has caused a lot of controversy and division within the sport.

While many players have been attracted to the LIV tour because of the larger payouts, lighter schedule and relaxed rules, it is clear that this tour is primarily focused on the players and their financial gain, rather than the competitive spirit of the game. This is evident in comments from players like Harold Varner III and Pat Perez, who have openly stated that they are more interested in getting paid than in winning. When Pat Perez was asked about his poor individual performance, despite being on the season-winning team, he commented ‚ÄòI‚Äôm paid. I don‚Äôt give a damn‚Äô

This shift in focus has left many golf fans, like myself, feeling disillusioned and disconnected from the sport. It is hard to get excited about watching the top players compete when it seems like winning is not their top priority.

Overall, while the decision to leave the traditional tours is personal, I still enjoy watching the top players compete and strive for victory on the PGA Tour.
